misc.DETACH:
LABEL_0 - Ending the dialogue. Saying goodbye or other similar actions.
Examples:
1. speaker_1: Okay, I have to go $$$ LABEL_0
speaker_2: Bye-bye $$$ LABEL_0
2. speaker_1: It's so nice! $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Sorry, I need to hurry $$$ LABEL_0
3. speaker_1: Can you help me? $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I can't talk right now, later $$$ LABEL_0
3. speaker_1: Good. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: Let's go now. $$$ LABEL_0
3. speaker_1: Well, I have to go to practice. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: See you later. $$$ LABEL_0
misc.REGISTER:
LABEL_1 - Repetition of words or phrases after the interlocutor, exclamations, emotional expressions
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: She bought a toy for my little sister.
speaker_2: It's so cute. $$$ LABEL_1
2. speaker_1: Thank you very much!
speaker_2: You're welcome. $$$ LABEL_1
3. speaker_1: Katy is so beautiful.
speaker_2: Yeah, so beautiful. $$$ LABEL_1
4. speaker_1: I've got two tickets for Taylor Swift's concert.
speaker_2: Wow, so cool! $$$ LABEL_1
5. speaker_1: He was absolutely right.
speaker_2: Absolutely right. $$$ LABEL_1
6. speaker_1: I got promoted to manager today!
speaker_2: Congratulations!  $$$ LABEL_1
7. speaker_1: I'm thinking of taking a trip to Europe this summer.
speaker_2: Wow! $$$ LABEL_1
8. speaker_1: I failed my driving test again.
speaker_2: Oh, don't worry!  $$$ LABEL_1
9. speaker_1: My favorite food is sushi.
speaker_2: Yeah $$$ LABEL_1
misc.ENGAGE:
LABEL_2 - Greeting or drawing attention
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: Hey! $$$ LABEL_2
speaker_2: Hi! $$$ LABEL_2
2. speaker_1: Mary!$$$ LABEL_2
3. speaker_1: Good morning! $$$ LABEL_2
speaker_2: Hey, Steve! $$$ LABEL_2
4. speaker_1: Good evening! $$$ LABEL_2
speaker_1: How are you? $$$ LABEL_2
5. speaker_1: Hey, man! $$$ LABEL_2
6. speaker_1: Come on, Tara $$$ LABEL_2
misc.ACCEPT:
LABEL_3 - expressing gratitude.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: I helped you fix your computer.
speaker_2: I'm very grateful for your help. $$$ LABEL_3
2. speaker_1: You are a great mentor to me.
speaker_2: Thank you! $$$ LABEL_3
3. speaker_1: I made dinner for you.
speaker_2: I appreciate this so much. $$$ LABEL_3
4. speaker_1: Congratulations! 
speaker_2: Thank you so much. $$$ LABEL_3
5. speaker_1: I'll drive you to the airport tomorrow morning.
speaker_2: Thank you, that's a huge help! $$$ LABEL_3

decl.REFUTE:
LABEL_4 - Refusing to move on to a new topic. It is NOT disagreement. It is refusal to discuss something.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: I’m out $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: You can’t do that, it’s my birthday $$$ LABEL_4
2. speaker_1: Well, come and talk to me then. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Certainly not. $$$ LABEL_4
3. speaker_1: Oh, God, we forgot to cheer for Daddy. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Never mind. $$$ LABEL_4
4. speaker_1: Tell me about Jane's new boyfriend. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Sorry, that's none of your business. $$$ LABEL_4
decl.EXTEND:
LABEL_5 - Adding supplementary or contradictory information to the previous statement. A declarative sentence or phrase (may include and, but, except, on the other hand)
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: I'll pay my own way.
speaker_1: I insist. $$$ LABEL_5
2. speaker_1: Men shake hands.
speaker_1: women and children don't. $$$ LABEL_5
3. speaker_1: You hit the white ball with your cue.
speaker_1: The white ball hits the colored balls. $$$ LABEL_5
4. speaker_1: Lovely day.
speaker_2: Pity I’m on duty. $$$ LABEL_5
5. speaker_1: That’s the worst insult you could throw at a Chinese stir fry.
speaker_1: What a disgrace to the wok she fried it in! $$$ LABEL_5
6. speaker_1: I would die for a plate of stir fry right now!
speaker_2: Well you can keep the vegetables.  $$$ LABEL_5
7. speaker_1: We’Ve always disagreed in a friendly way and we have always resolved our differences.
speaker_2: It was the same when I made this movie. $$$ LABEL_5
decl.ELABORATE:
LABEL_6 - Clarifying or rephrasing the previous statement or giving examples to it.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: Then stay away. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: No one is keeping you from doing that. $$$ LABEL_6
2. speaker_1: I bought some useful staff today. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: I mean evrything we need for our party. $$$ LABEL_6
3. speaker_1: I heard the public transportation in that city is very good. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: I heard that it costs not so much in comparison to other cities and still in great condition. $$$ LABEL_6
4. speaker_1: Ariana Grande canceled her tour. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: We need to refund the tickets. $$$ LABEL_6
5. speaker_1: I'm so disappointed by his indifference. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: He forgot about my birthday. $$$ LABEL_6
decl.ENHANCE:
LABEL_7 - Adding details to the previous statement, adding information about time, place, reason, etc.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: Katty Perry is a great performer. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: We've been to her show in Las Vegas. $$$ LABEL_7
2. speaker_1: I need to buy a new dress for this evening. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: It has to be in the disco style. $$$ LABEL_7
3. speaker_1: I think the sun is going to explode soon. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: It's becoming hotter every year. $$$ LABEL_7
4. speaker_1: I heard a story about a robbery in Amsterdam $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: An old lady was robbed of her dog. $$$ LABEL_7
5. speaker_1: You're his best friend. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: Since his childhood. $$$ LABEL_7
6. speaker_1: This is her favourite song. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: I knew this from her feed on VK. $$$ LABEL_7
7. speaker_1: This is the newest theory about implementing new technology to our project. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: It was developed by Mr.Sadman. $$$ LABEL_7
decl.AGREE:
LABEL_8 - Agreement with the information provided. In most cases, the information that the speaker agrees with is new to him. Yes/its synonyms or affirmation.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: She is the best singer in the world.
speaker_2: Yeah, she is amazing. $$$ LABEL_8
2. speaker_1: The service at this hotel is excellent.
speaker_2: I totally agree, they're so attentive. $$$ LABEL_8
3. speaker_1: It's perfect day for a barbecue.
speaker_2: It sure is. $$$ LABEL_8
4. speaker_1: That sounds interesting.
speaker_2: Yeah. $$$ LABEL_8
5. speaker_1: Would you like to join us? 
speaker_2: Absolutely. $$$ LABEL_8
6. speaker_1: I don't like movies that are too slow-paced.
speaker_2: Neither do I, they're too boring.  $$$ LABEL_8
7. speaker_1: Can you recommend a good sushi place?
speaker_2: Yes, I love the one on 5th Avenue. $$$ LABEL_8
decl.AFFIRM:
LABEL_9 - A positive answer to a question or confirmation of the information provided. Yes/its synonyms or affirmation. The speaker usually confirms the information that he already knew before.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: David always makes a mess in our room.
speaker_2: Yeah, he does. $$$ LABEL_9
2. speaker_1: Is it true they ended up together?
speaker_2: Their wedding was last month. $$$ LABEL_9
3. speaker_1: Are you moving to Paris?
speaker_2: Yeah, that's true. $$$ LABEL_9
4. speaker_1: Is it going to rain later today?
speaker_2: The forecast says so. $$$ LABEL_9
5. speaker_1: Can I bring my own food into the theater?
speaker_2: You can bring your own snacks. $$$ LABEL_9
6. speaker_1: I heard you're fluent in Spanish.
speaker_2: I grew up speaking it at home.  $$$ LABEL_9
7. speaker_1: You defended our project and got excellent feedback, yeah?
speaker_2: We did it. $$$ LABEL_9
decl.DISAVOW:
LABEL_10 - Denial of knowledge or understanding of information
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: Can you recommend a good book to read?
speaker_2: I'm not familiar with any. $$$ LABEL_10
2. speaker_1: Can you tell me how to solve this math problem?
speaker_2: I'm not sure. $$$ LABEL_10
3. speaker_1: Are they dating?
speaker_2: I have no clue about it. $$$ LABEL_10
4. speaker_1: Is the new coffee blend good?
speaker_2: Maybe. $$$ LABEL_10
5. speaker_1: She's a good manager.
speaker_2: I don't know. $$$ LABEL_10
6. speaker_1: The Shining is definitely the best Steven King's work.
speaker_2: I'm not aware of this one.  $$$ LABEL_10
7. speaker_1: We have a test on Monday.
speaker_2: I had no idea about this. $$$ LABEL_10
decl.ACKNOWLEDGE:
LABEL_11 - Indicating knowledge or understanding of the information provided
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: This house doesn't belong to him. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I knew it. $$$ LABEL_11
2. speaker_1: This's my personal task $$$ OTHER
speaker_2:  I see. $$$ LABEL_11
3. speaker_1: I'm a fan of horror movies. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I'm aware of this fact. $$$ LABEL_11
4. speaker_1: She is the most arrogant lady in the city $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I knew it from the very beginning. $$$ LABEL_11
5. speaker_1: I'm in love with her $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I understand why. $$$ LABEL_11
6. speaker_1: Is it the best recipe? $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I'm sure. $$$ LABEL_11
7. speaker_1: He'll buy this castle. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I have no doubts about it. $$$ LABEL_11
8. speaker_1: Katy is a future pop star $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I know that for sure. $$$ LABEL_11
9. speaker_1: He kissed her at school. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: I know $$$ LABEL_11
decl.DISAGREE:
LABEL_12 - Negative answers or nos to a question or denial of a statement. In most cases, the information that the speaker disagrees with is new to him.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: She is the best choice for this position.
speaker_2: That's not true. $$$ LABEL_12
2. speaker_1: That movie was so boring, I fell asleep halfway through.
speaker_2: As for me, it was pretty interesting. $$$ LABEL_12
3. speaker_1: Katty is perfect, right?
speaker_2: I don't think so. $$$ LABEL_12
4. speaker_1: Can you help me?
speaker_2: I'm actually very busy right now. $$$ LABEL_12
5. speaker_1: Do you think Beyonce is overrated?
speaker_2: No way, she's a queen! $$$ LABEL_12
6. speaker_1: I think the first movie is the best one.
speaker_2: I prefer the later ones when the story gets darker.  $$$ LABEL_12
7. speaker_1: Harry Potter movies are too dark, aren't they?
speaker_2: They are just appropriate for the tone of the books.  $$$ LABEL_12
decl.RESOLVE:
LABEL_13 - A detailed answer to the question asked. This does not include negative or positive answers, as well as expressions of agreement or disagreement, understanding or lack of understanding.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: Who is your favorite character in Harry Potter?
speaker_2: Hermione Granger. $$$ LABEL_13
2. speaker_1: How do you feel about the grading system?
speaker_2: I think it's fair and necessary to measure student progress. $$$ LABEL_13
3. speaker_1: Do you think online learning is as effective as in-person learning?
speaker_2: It can be just as effective if done properly, but there are some drawbacks. $$$ LABEL_13
4. speaker_1: What is your major?
speaker_2: Linguistics. $$$ LABEL_13
5. speaker_1: What's your opinion on homeschooling?
speaker_2: I think it can work well for some families, but it's not for everyone. $$$ LABEL_13
6. speaker_1: Do you speak Spanish or German?
speaker_2: Actually, both.  $$$ LABEL_13
7. speaker_1: Do you have any tips for packing efficiently?
speaker_2: Roll your clothes instead of folding them. $$$ LABEL_13
decl.CONTRADICT:
LABEL_14 - Contradicting previous information, mostly a speaker already knew before.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: This book is a classic.
speaker_1: Actually, it's not well-regarded in literary circles. $$$ LABEL_14
2. speaker_1: Is the music too loud for you?
speaker_1: Not at all. $$$ LABEL_14
3. speaker_1: Are you a fan of horror movies?
speaker_1: No, I can't stand them. $$$ LABEL_14
4. speaker_1: Do you like this color?
speaker_2: No, it's too bright for my taste.  $$$ LABEL_14
5. speaker_1: I believe this is the best restaurant in town.
speaker_2: In fact, the restaurant has terrible reviews and a low rating. $$$ LABEL_14
6. speaker_1: I have never broken a bone in my body.
speaker_2: You broke your arm when you were a kid.  $$$ LABEL_14
7. speaker_1: The train is coming at 3 PM.
speaker_2: Actually, it's coming at 4 PM. $$$ LABEL_14

questions.CHECK:
LABEL_15 - Make the previous speaker repeat something. NB: Only used to ask to repeat something they did not hear.
Examples:
1. speaker_1: And they headed straight into the forest. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Straight into the what? $$$ LABEL_15
2. speaker_1: Our friendship is over. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: What do you mean? $$$ LABEL_15
3. speaker_1: Do you know Sally? $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Sally? $$$ LABEL_15
4. speaker_1: I think that's impossible! $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: You mean 30 push-ups? $$$ LABEL_15
5. speaker_1: She taught us that you can do anything that you want to do. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Anything? $$$ LABEL_15
questions.CONFIRM:
LABEL_16 - Asking to confirmation the information to make sure they understood correctly.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: Well, he rang Roman, he rang Roman a week ago. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Did he? $$$ LABEL_16
2. speaker_1: It will help us to relax. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Do you really think so? $$$ LABEL_16
3. speaker_1: I can do 30 push-ups a minute. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Really? $$$ LABEL_16
4. speaker_1: I play goalie myself. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Oh, yeah? $$$ LABEL_16
5. speaker_1: Do you believe this? $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Is he really? $$$ LABEL_16
6. speaker_1: And who’ll cook dinner? $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: Will you? $$$ LABEL_16
7. speaker_1: I found a new way to learn Chinese and it works very well. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: You did? $$$ LABEL_16
questions.CLARIFY:
LABEL_17 - Asking a question to get additional information to understand the previous speaker better. Can be yes-no question.
Examples:
1. speaker_1: I am going to visit Anya tomorrow.
speaker_2: Where does she live? $$$ LABEL_17
1. speaker_1: I am so sad.
speaker_1: Has anything happened? $$$ LABEL_17
2. speaker_1: She really didn’t have any teacher’s pets.
speaker_2: Do you know what she is doing now? $$$ LABEL_17
3. speaker_1: Then, she started writing children’s book.
speaker_2: Have you ever read one of the books? $$$ LABEL_17
5. speaker_1: Why? $$$ LABEL_17
speaker_1: What had you expected? $$$ LABEL_17
6. speaker_1: Do you think she is stupid? $$$ LABEL_17
questions.PROBE:
LABEL_18 - Requesting a confirmation of some information. The speaker themselves speculates about this information. NB: The speaker asks a question to confirm their own idea.
Examples:
1. speaker_1: Then they went to visit Roman. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Because Roman lives in Denning Road also? $$$ LABEL_18
2. speaker_1: You just sit there in a daze, gazing at the monitor and dealing with files and documents. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Why don't you give a full play to your energy after work? $$$ LABEL_18
3. speaker_1: Great. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Is it a two bedroom house? $$$ LABEL_18
4. speaker_1: The Filipino kid is a genius. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: So you'll make the Stars.com deadline, and have us up and running next week? $$$ LABEL_18
5. speaker_1: Come by any time. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Shall I say around ten o'clock? $$$ LABEL_18
6. speaker_1: They have a big new fancy house. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Does Jim make a lot of money? $$$ LABEL_18
7. speaker_1: You said she was strict. $$$ OTHER
speaker_1: Did she have a lot of rules? $$$ LABEL_18
questions.REBOUND:
LABEL_19 - Questioning the relevance, reliability of the previous statement. Must be interrogative.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: This conversation needs Allenby. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Who are you to say that? $$$ LABEL_19
6. speaker_1: It will help us to relax. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Do you really think so? $$$ LABEL_19
7. speaker_1: I can do 30 push-ups a minute. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Really? $$$ LABEL_19
8. speaker_1: I won't. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: So what's the problem? $$$ LABEL_19
9. speaker_1: Anything? $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Do you really believe that we can do anything? $$$ LABEL_19
questions.RECHALLENGE:
LABEL_20 - Offering an alternative position. Must be interrogative.
Examples:
1.  speaker_1: Messi is the best. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Maybe Pele is the best one? $$$ LABEL_20
2. speaker_1: Mary, I really like your new dress. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: The old one is better, don't you think so? $$$ LABEL_20
3. speaker_1: So that we can sit down together and listen to some music. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Listen to some music? And who’ll cook dinner? $$$ LABEL_20
4. speaker_1: She don’t have any teacher’s pets. $$$ OTHER
speaker_2: Doesn’t every teacher have a teacher’s pet? $$$ LABEL_20

upper_level.DECLARATIVE:
LABEL_21 - declarative sentences, contain affirmation or denial of some facts, events, or actions. NB! If a sentence contains an order, a request or a suggesion, it is included into this category.
Examples:
1. I can’t stand him. $$$ LABEL_21
2. She then decided to travel alone. $$$ LABEL_21
3. You should not do it. $$$ LABEL_21
upper_level.MISCELLANEOUS:
LABEL_22 - sentences (usually short) that are used to express gratitude, manifest emotions, display attention to the previous speaker, draw the speaker's attention
Examples:
1. Thank you! $$$ LABEL_22
2. Oh my god! $$$ LABEL_22
3. Great! $$$ LABEL_22
4. Sounds good. $$$ LABEL_22
5. Alright. $$$ LABEL_22
6. Hey there! $$$ LABEL_22
7. Morning! $$$ LABEL_22
8. David! $$$ LABEL_22
upper_level.INTERROGATIVE:
LABEL_23 - contains a question of some kind. NB! An interrogative sentence may end with a dot as well as with a question mark.
Examples:
1. Do you like dancing? $$$ LABEL_23
2. What has he done? $$$ LABEL_23
3. You must have been there many times. $$$ LABEL_23
4. I’d like to know what plans you’ve got for tomorrow. $$$ LABEL_23
upper_level.COMMAND:
LABEL_24 - a command, a request or an invitation.
Examples:
1. Let’s discuss this later. $$$ LABEL_24
2. Let's talk about something else. $$$ LABEL_24
3. Could you give me that book? $$$ LABEL_24
4. How about going to London? $$$ LABEL_24
